citation.article-title: Capnocytophaga haemolytica sp. nov. and Capnocytophaga granulosa sp. nov., from human dental plaque.

p.s: Description of Capnocytophaga haemolytica sp. nov.
Capnocytophaga haemolytica (hae.mo.ly'ti.ca. Gr. n. haema, blood; Gr. adj. lyticus, dissolving; M. L. fem. adj. haemolytica, blood dissolving)
Cells are thin, gram-negative rods (2 to 4 by 0.2 to 0.3 μm).
Flat, thin colonies are 1 to 2 mm in diameter after 5 to 7 days of anaerobic incubation at 37°C on TBBP agar.
Beta-hemolysis is observed on TBBP agar after primary isolation isolation is reduced or lost after a few subcultures.
The colonial
colors are gray or purple on TBBP agar and blood agar but yellow or orange on Trypticase soy agar.
Pellets of cells obtained by centrifugation after washing with distilled water are yellow or orange.
Cultures grow under microaerophilic conditions and can grow well on blood agar incubated at 37°C in the presence of 5% CO2.
Positive for nitrate reduction and esculin hydrolysis.
Susceptible to actinomycin D.
Produces acids from D-glucose, glycogen, D-lactose, D-maltose, D-mannose, starch, and D-sucrose; 63% of the strains produce acids from dextran and inulin.
Negative for oxidase activity, catalase activity, H2S production, and indole production.
No acid is produced from cellulose, D-mannitol, D-ribose, D-sorbitol, and D-xylose.
No aminopeptidase activity is observed with the substrates listed in Table 4.
The major end products of glucose fermentation are acetate and succinate.
The major menaquinone is MK-6.
The dominant cellular fatty acids are i-15:O (13-methyltetradecanoic) and 18:O (octadecanoic) acids.
The G+C content of the DNA is 43 to 44 mol%.
Strain A0404 (= JCM 8565) is the type strain of C. haemolytica.
The characteristics of this strain are the same as those given above for the species.
The G+C content of the DNA of this strain is 44.0 mol%.
